title: Modals: May / Might / Could
description: Слушайте модальные глаголы вероятности: may, might, could.

tasks.audioText: Dark clouds are gathering on the horizon. It might rain heavily later this afternoon.
tasks.transcript: It might rain heavily later this afternoon.

options.text: It will definitely rain this afternoon.
There is a possibility of heavy rain later today.
It rained heavily this morning.
It is impossible for it to rain today.

tasks.explanation: 'Might' expresses possibility, not certainty. The speaker sees signs of rain but isn't sure it will happen.

tasks.audioText: I haven't seen James at the office today. He may be working from home because he mentioned feeling unwell yesterday.
tasks.transcript: He may be working from home because he mentioned feeling unwell yesterday.

options.text: He is definitely working from home today.
It is possible that he is working from home since he was not feeling well.
He quit his job yesterday.
He is at the office but hiding somewhere.

tasks.explanation: 'May be working' expresses a present possibility based on available evidence — he felt unwell, so home working is likely.

tasks.audioText: The restaurant on the corner looks interesting. We could try it for dinner tonight if you are free.
tasks.transcript: We could try it for dinner tonight if you are free.

options.text: We are definitely going to that restaurant tonight.
The speaker is suggesting the restaurant as a possible option for dinner.
We already tried the restaurant last night.
The restaurant is closed tonight.

tasks.explanation: 'Could try' makes a polite suggestion — it presents the restaurant as one possible option, not a firm plan.

tasks.audioText: The exam results haven't been posted yet. The professor might announce them during tomorrow's lecture.
tasks.transcript: The professor might announce them during tomorrow's lecture.

options.text: The professor will certainly share the results tomorrow.
There is a chance the professor will reveal the results in tomorrow's class.
The professor already announced the results today.
The professor will never share the exam results.

tasks.explanation: 'Might announce' indicates uncertainty about a future event — the announcement is possible but not guaranteed.

tasks.audioText: Excuse me, I'm looking for the post office. Could you tell me how to get there from here?
tasks.transcript: Could you tell me how to get there from here?

options.text: The speaker is politely asking for directions to the post office.
The speaker is demanding directions aggressively.
The speaker already knows where the post office is.
The speaker is telling someone how to get to the post office.

tasks.explanation: 'Could you tell me' is a polite request using 'could'. The speaker is asking for help with directions.

tasks.audioText: The shares have been fluctuating wildly all week. The market may stabilise by the end of the quarter, but experts are uncertain.
tasks.transcript: The market may stabilise by the end of the quarter, but experts are uncertain.

options.text: The market will definitely stabilise soon.
Stabilisation of the market is a possibility, but nobody is sure it will happen.
The market has already stabilised completely.
Experts are certain the market will crash.

tasks.explanation: 'May stabilise' expresses possibility, reinforced by 'experts are uncertain' — the outcome is not guaranteed.

tasks.audioText: I left my umbrella somewhere yesterday. I might have left it at the café when I stopped for coffee.
tasks.transcript: I might have left it at the café when I stopped for coffee.

options.text: I definitely left the umbrella at the café.
It is possible that the café is where I forgot my umbrella.
I brought the umbrella home from the café.
I never went to a café yesterday.

tasks.explanation: 'Might have left' expresses a past possibility — the speaker is guessing about where the umbrella was forgotten.

tasks.audioText: The new treatment is still in clinical trials. It could potentially help millions of patients with chronic pain.
tasks.transcript: It could potentially help millions of patients with chronic pain.

options.text: The treatment is already helping millions of patients.
The treatment has the potential to benefit a huge number of chronic pain sufferers.
The treatment will never be effective.
The treatment was discontinued after trials.

tasks.explanation: 'Could potentially help' combines 'could' with 'potentially' to express a future possibility — the treatment is promising but unproven.

tasks.audioText: May I borrow your laptop for a few minutes? I need to check something urgently and mine has just run out of battery.
tasks.transcript: May I borrow your laptop for a few minutes?

options.text: The speaker is formally requesting permission to use someone's laptop briefly.
The speaker is offering their laptop to someone.
The speaker already borrowed the laptop.
The speaker doesn't need a laptop at all.

tasks.explanation: 'May I' is a formal way to ask for permission. The speaker politely requests to use the laptop temporarily.

tasks.audioText: The new employee seems very talented. She could become one of our best designers if she continues to develop her skills.
tasks.transcript: She could become one of our best designers if she continues to develop her skills.

options.text: She is already the best designer in the company.
She has the potential to be among the top designers with further skill development.
She will definitely leave the company soon.
She could not become a good designer under any circumstances.

tasks.explanation: 'Could become' expresses potential ability — with continued growth, becoming a top designer is possible.

tasks.audioText: We're planning a trip to Iceland next month. The northern lights may be visible if we're lucky with the weather conditions.
tasks.transcript: The northern lights may be visible if we're lucky with the weather conditions.

options.text: We will definitely see the northern lights in Iceland.
There is a chance of seeing the aurora if weather permits.
Northern lights are visible in Iceland every night.
Northern lights cannot be seen in Iceland.

tasks.explanation: 'May be visible' expresses possibility — seeing the northern lights depends on weather, so it's uncertain.

tasks.audioText: The strange noise in the engine is concerning. It might be a problem with the transmission, but we need a mechanic to confirm.
tasks.transcript: It might be a problem with the transmission, but we need a mechanic to confirm.

options.text: The mechanic confirmed it is a transmission problem.
A transmission issue is one possible explanation, but it hasn't been verified yet.
There is nothing wrong with the engine.
The transmission was replaced yesterday.

tasks.explanation: 'Might be' expresses an unconfirmed possibility — the speaker suspects a transmission issue but needs professional diagnosis.

tasks.audioText: The archaeologists are very excited about the discovery. The artefacts they found could date back over three thousand years.
tasks.transcript: The artefacts they found could date back over three thousand years.

options.text: The artefacts are confirmed to be exactly three thousand years old.
It is possible that the artefacts are more than three millennia old.
The artefacts were made last year.
The artefacts cannot be dated by any method.

tasks.explanation: 'Could date back' expresses uncertain possibility about the age — the artefacts might be very ancient, but it's not confirmed.

tasks.audioText: I'm not sure why Lisa hasn't responded to my message yet. She may not have seen it because she mentioned her phone was broken.
tasks.transcript: She may not have seen it because she mentioned her phone was broken.

options.text: She definitely didn't see the message.
It is possible she hasn't read the message due to phone issues.
She saw the message but chose not to reply.
Her phone works perfectly fine.

tasks.explanation: 'May not have seen' expresses past possibility in the negative — a broken phone could explain why the message wasn't read.

tasks.audioText: The company is considering expanding to Asia. They might open their first office in Singapore or Tokyo within the next two years.
tasks.transcript: They might open their first office in Singapore or Tokyo within the next two years.

options.text: They already have offices in Singapore and Tokyo.
They are certain to open in both Singapore and Tokyo.
There is a possibility of opening an Asian office in Singapore or Tokyo in the near future.
They have no plans to expand anywhere.

tasks.explanation: 'Might open' expresses a future possibility — expansion to Asia is being considered but not decided.
